description.summary: Divine bird creature in Hindu and Buddhist mythology, mount of Vishnu and king of birds. Depicted with eagle or hawk features, human body, golden feathers, and massive size. Eternal enemy of nagas (serpents) and protector deity.
description.full: Garuda is a divine bird creature central to Hindu and Buddhist mythology. As the mount (vahana) of the god Vishnu, Garuda is depicted with a golden eagle or hawk head, massive wings, talons, and often a crowned human form. He is the king of birds and possesses superhuman strength, flight, immortality, and sun-like radiance. Garuda's most defining characteristic is his eternal rivalry with the nagas (serpents), against whom he serves as protector. In Hindu mythology, Garuda obtained the nectar of immortality (amrita) to free his mother from slavery. He is revered as a protector against serpents and poison. Garuda serves as a national symbol in Indonesia and Thailand, appears on national emblems and airline logos (Garuda Indonesia), and remains prominent in temple architecture and popular culture throughout South and Southeast Asia.

history.modern_era: Garuda remains central to Hindu and Buddhist religious practice. Serves as national symbol of Indonesia (Garuda Pancasila) and Thailand (Krut). Featured in airline branding (Garuda Indonesia), government seals, and popular culture across Asia.

mythology.birth_story: Garuda was born from an egg laid by his mother Vinata after a prolonged gestation. His father was the sage Kashyapa. Upon hatching, his radiance was so great he was mistaken for Agni, the fire god.
mythology.amrita_quest: To free his mother from slavery to the nagas, Garuda had to obtain the amrita (nectar of immortality) from the gods. He successfully stole it through great strength and cunning, defeating the gods' guardians. Vishnu was impressed and offered him a boon, leading Garuda to become his mount. Indra later recovered the amrita.
mythology.eternal_enmity: The eternal conflict between Garuda and the nagas stems from a wager between his mother Vinata and her sister Kadru (mother of nagas), which resulted in Vinata's enslavement. This cosmic rivalry represents the conflict between sky and earth, light and darkness.

symbolism.spiritual_significance: Garuda represents the soul's liberation from material bondage (symbolized by serpents). His quest for amrita parallels spiritual seeking. In Buddhism, he embodies the dharma's power to overcome obstacles.

folklore.beliefs: Garuda protects against snake bites and poison. Invoked for protection during travel. Symbol of righteous power overcoming evil.

national_symbols.indonesia: Garuda Pancasila - national emblem showing Garuda with shield containing five principles of Indonesian state philosophy
national_symbols.thailand: Phra Khrut Pha - royal symbol, appears on government seals and royal regalia
national_symbols.mongolia: Khangarid - national symbol appearing on emblems

cultural_sensitivity.note: Garuda is part of living Hindu and Buddhist religious traditions and serves as national symbol for multiple countries. Not merely a mythological creature but an object of veneration and national pride.
